case_name: Jetha Nand Betab v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 490 of 1860 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 490 of 1860.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 6, 1958 of Punjab High Court in Civil Misc. No. 28 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Misc. No. 28 of 1958 File A . Mohan Behari Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by DAS GUPTA, J. on December 5, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. December 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-The appellant, Jetha Nand  Betab  was enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind on May 14, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant Jetha Nand Betab enrolled as Advocate in Chief Court of Sind on May 14, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Jetha Nand  Betab  was enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind on May 14, 1947. He came away to India at the end of the year 1948 and practised in the companyrts at Delhi.

facts.text: Appellant came to India at the end of 1948 and practised in courts at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: He came away to India at the end of the year 1948 and practised in the companyrts at Delhi. On October 8, 1956 an order was passed by the Chief Justice of the Punjab High Court prohibiting the appellant from practising as an Advocate in the companyrts at Delhi.

facts.text: On October 8, 1956, Chief Justice of Punjab High Court passed order prohibiting appellant from practising in courts at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On October 8, 1956 an order was passed by the Chief Justice of the Punjab High Court prohibiting the appellant from practising as an Advocate in the companyrts at Delhi. On November 8, 1956 the appellant presented an application to the High Court in which he companytended that by virtue of his having been enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind he was entitled to practice in all the subordinate companyrts within the territory of India.

facts.text: On November 8, 1956, appellant presented application to Punjab High Court claiming right to practice in all subordinate courts in India based on Sind enrollment.

anchor.surface_text: On November 8, 1956 the appellant presented an application to the High Court in which he companytended that by virtue of his having been enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind he was entitled to practice in all the subordinate companyrts within the territory of India. This petition was however rejected by a Full Bench of the Punjab High Court on the view that the appellant companyld number after the partition of India be companysidered to be an Advocate enrolled under the provisions of the Bar Councils Act.

facts.text: Punjab High Court rejected appellant's petition by Full Bench on October 6, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was however rejected by a Full Bench of the Punjab High Court on the view that the appellant companyld number after the partition of India be companysidered to be an Advocate enrolled under the provisions of the Bar Councils Act. Against this order the present appeal has been preferred on special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the present appeal has been preferred on special leave granted by this Court. The petitioners case is that as immediately before the partition of India he was entitled to practise in any companyrt in British India his right to practise in those Courts companytinued to exist even when on partition of India, British India ceased to exist and provinces of India took their place and when thereafter on the formation of the Indian Union under the Constitution these provinces became States of India but those same companyrts companytinued, his right to practise in those companyrts also companytinued.

facts.text: Petitioner claims right to practice continued post-partition due to pre-partition entitlement in British India.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case is that as immediately before the partition of India he was entitled to practise in any companyrt in British India his right to practise in those Courts companytinued to exist even when on partition of India, British India ceased to exist and provinces of India took their place and when thereafter on the formation of the Indian Union under the Constitution these provinces became States of India but those same companyrts companytinued, his right to practise in those companyrts also companytinued. On behalf of the respondents it is companytended that the petitioners right to practise in companyrts which were number under the Chief Court of Sind ceased as soon as Sind ceased to form part of India and the Chief Court of Sind ceased to be a High Court in India.

facts.text: Respondents contend petitioner's right ceased when Sind ceased to be part of India.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it is companytended that the petitioners right to practise in companyrts which were number under the Chief Court of Sind ceased as soon as Sind ceased to form part of India and the Chief Court of Sind ceased to be a High Court in India. As the appellant bases his claim on s. 14  1   b  of the Indian Bar Councils Act, it is necessary to examine first the scheme of that Act.

facts.text: Governor-General notified Chief Court of Sind as High Court to which Indian Bar Councils Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us that the Governor-General by numberification in the Gazette of India did declare the Chief Court of Sind to be a High Court to which this Act applied and that by another numberification he also directed that all the provisions of the Act would companye into force in respect of the Chief Court of Sind on some date long before 1947.

facts.text: All provisions of Indian Bar Councils Act came into force for Chief Court of Sind long before 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and that by another numberification he also directed that all the provisions of the Act would companye into force in respect of the Chief Court of Sind on some date long before 1947. Consequently, even though these numberifications have number been placed before us we must proceed on the bases that on May 14, 1947, when the appellant was enrolled as an advocate in the Chief Court of Sind he was an advocate for the purposes of the Indian Bar Councils Act and so was entitled as of right to practise in any subordinate companyrts in what then was British India.

facts.text: Partition of India on appointed day August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In this Order, the appointed dated was defined as August 15, 1947. Section 5 of the Order is in these words - Any reference in an existing Indian law to a High Court which as from the appointed day ceases to be a High Court for any part of the Dominion of India, shall  a  if the reference be to the High Court of Judicature at Lahore, be replaced by a reference to the High Court of East Punjab, and  b  in any other case, be omitted.

facts.text: Chief Court of Sind ceased to be High Court for Dominion of India from August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Court of Sind  a High Court within the meaning of the General Clauses Act  having ceased as from August 15, 1947 to be a High Court for any part of the Dominion of India references to that Court as one to which the Act applied must be omitted in the application of the Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926 after that date.

facts.text: India Adaptation of Existing Indian Laws Order, 1947 omitted references to Chief Court of Sind as High Court post August 14, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the Chief Court of Sind which was a High Court for the purposes of the Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926 up to the August 14, 1947 ceased to exist as a High Court for the purposes of the Indian Bar Councils Act with effect from the 15th day of August, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant's right to practice under s.14 Indian Bar Councils Act ceased from August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary companysequence of this is that the roll maintained by the Chief Court of Sind was from August 15, 1947 numberlonger a roll maintained by a High Court within the meaning of the Indian Bar Councils Act and thus any person whose name was entered on the roll of the Chief Court of Sind ceased to be an advocate for the purpose of s. 14 of the Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926 and therefore ceased to have the right under that section to practise in companyrts in India.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly rejected the appellants application. The appeal is accordingly dismissed. In the circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: No order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly dismissed. In the circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Indian Bar Councils Act applied to Chief Court of Sind by notification before 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, even though these numberifications have number been placed before us we must proceed on the bases that on May 14, 1947, when the appellant was enrolled as an advocate in the Chief Court of Sind he was an advocate for the purposes of the Indian Bar Councils Act and so was entitled as of right to practise in any subordinate companyrts in what then was British India.

concepts.interpretation: Appellant claims entitlement to practice in subordinate courts based on enrollment; court holds right ceases post-partition as no longer an 'advocate' under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 defined Advocate as an advocate entered in the roll of advocates of a High Court under the provisions of this Act and High Court as a High Court to which this Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Jetha Nand Betab was enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind on May 14, 1947. He came away to India at the end of the year 1948 and practised in the courts at Delhi. On October 8, 1956 an order was passed by the Chief Justice of the Punjab High Court prohibiting the appellant from practising as an Advocate in the courts at Delhi.

concepts.interpretation: Statutory right under Bar Councils Act ceases when no longer enrolled on qualifying roll post-Adaptation Order.
concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory right of advocates to practice in subordinate courts.

issues.text: whether by virtue of having been enrolled as an Advocate in the Chief Court of Sind he was entitled to practice in all the subordinate courts within the territory of India

whether the petitioner's right to practise in courts which were under the Chief Court of Sind ceased as soon as Sind ceased to form part of India and the Chief Court of Sind ceased to be a High Court in India
whether this right continued to exist after Sind ceased to form a part of India
What is the position if the High Court ceases to exist, by reason of abolition or otherwise?
whether the appellant could after the partition of India be considered to be an Advocate enrolled under the provisions of the Bar Councils Act

anchor.surface_text: This petition was however rejected by a Full Bench of the Punjab High Court on the view that the appellant could not after the partition of India be considered to be an Advocate enrolled under the provisions of the Bar Councils Act.

arguments.claim: Advocate defined as one whose name continues on roll of High Court to which Act applies

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us clear that when s. 2 defines advocate as an advocate entered in the roll of advocates of High Court, it means an advocate who has been entered in such roll of advocates and whose name continues to be on that roll.

arguments.claim: Like removal under s.12, cessation from roll ends advocate status

anchor.surface_text: When, for example, the name of the advocate is removed from the roll under s. 12 he ceases to be an advocate within the meaning of s. 14 in spite of the fact that his name was once entered in that roll.

arguments.claim: If High Court ceases to exist, roll has no legal existence, person no longer advocate

anchor.surface_text: What is the position if the High Court ceases to exist, by reason of abolition or otherwise ? The only possible answer to this question is that if the High Court ceases to exist the roll which used to be maintained by it has also no legal existence

arguments.claim: Chief Court of Sind ceased to be High Court for Bar Councils Act post Aug 15, 1947 per Adaptation Order s.5

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Court of Sind a High Court within the meaning of the General Clauses Act having ceased as from August 15, 1947 to be a High Court for any part of the Dominion of India references to that Court as one to which the Act applied must be omitted

arguments.claim: Adaptation Order prevents future exercise of rights based on former High Courts now in Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt whatsoever that in making this adaptation in s. 5 of the India Adaptation of Existing Indian Laws Order, 1947 the intention of the authority making the order was not only to ensure that rights will not in future accrue on the basis of a High Court now in Pakistan

arguments.claim: Absence of disciplinary court anomalous if right continued

anchor.surface_text: We need merely add that if the appellants contention was correct, the anomalous position would have arisen that there would be no court in India which could take disciplinary action against him, in the event of misconduct.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Act requires each High Court to have disciplinary jurisdiction over its advocates

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Bar Councils Act is as has been emphasised earlier, that each High Court in the country should have disciplinary jurisdiction over the Advocates on its rolls. The provisions of the Adaptation order have maintained this position.

holdings.text: An advocate under s.2 of the Indian Bar Councils Act is one whose name has been entered in the roll of a High Court and continues to be on that roll.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us clear that when s. 2 defines advocate as an advocate entered in the roll of advocates of High Court, it means an advocate who has been entered in such roll of advocates and whose name continues to be on that roll.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of definition in s.2 requiring ongoing entry on roll, analogous to removal under s.12.

holdings.text: If a High Court ceases to exist, the roll maintained by it has no legal existence and persons on that roll are no longer advocates under s.14 or other sections of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: What is the position if the High Court ceases to exist, by reason of abolition or otherwise ? The only possible answer to this question is that if the High Court ceases to exist the roll which used to be maintained by it has also no legal existence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of High Court non-existence ends legal status of its roll; analogy to removal from roll.

holdings.text: Chief Court of Sind ceased to be a High Court for the Dominion of India from August 15, 1947, and references to it must be omitted under s.5(b) of the India Adaptation of Existing Indian Laws Order, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Court of Sind a High Court within the meaning of the General Clauses Act having ceased as from August 15, 1947 to be a High Court for any part of the Dominion of India references to that Court as one to which the Act applied must be omitted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.5 Adaptation Order to Chief Court of Sind as it ceased to function for any part of Dominion of India.

holdings.text: The roll of the Chief Court of Sind was from August 15, 1947 no longer maintained by a High Court under the Indian Bar Councils Act, so appellant ceased to be an advocate under s.14 and lost right to practise in courts in India.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary consequence of this is that the roll maintained by the Chief Court of Sind was from August 15, 1947 no longer a roll maintained by a High Court within the meaning of the Indian Bar Councils Act and thus any person whose name

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of Adaptation Order omitting references: roll loses status under Act, ending advocate qualification per s.2 and s.14.

holdings.text: Adaptation Order s.5 intended not only to prevent future rights accruing based on High Courts now in Pakistan but also to prevent future exercise of vested rights based on such courts.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt whatsoever that in making this adaptation in s. 5 of the India Adaptation of Existing Indian Laws Order, 1947 the intention of the authority making the order was not only to ensure that rights will not in future accrue

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation from absence of saving clause in Adaptation Order.

holdings.text: The Punjab High Court rightly rejected the appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly rejected the appellants application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of lower court based on above legal analysis.

holdings.text: Scheme of Bar Councils Act requires each High Court to have disciplinary jurisdiction over advocates on its rolls, maintained by Adaptation Order.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Bar Councils Act is as has been emphasised earlier, that each High Court in the country should have disciplinary jurisdiction over the Advocates on its rolls. The provisions of the Adaptation order have maintained this position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction supporting interpretation; highlights anomaly if appellant's claim accepted (no disciplinary court).
